d: Judgments and decrees.
Senseless judicial decisions.
Inhuman decisions of king.
Inhuman decision of king: sends man's sons to certain death and then murders man.
Deity settles disputes between races.
Irrevocable judgments.
Irrevocable judgment causes judge to suffer first.
r: Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 353; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
a: Has decreed that no one enter a meeting armed. He forgets to remove his sword. Kills himself.

d: Irrevocable sentence carried out even when innocence is proved.
a: A knight condemned for murdering his comrade is met by the latter on the way to the gallows. A centurion leads them to the emperor, who condemns all three to death: first because he has been sentenced; second for causing by his absence the conviction of his comrade; third for delay in the execution.

d: Sentence applied to king's own son.
r: *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 226; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
a: Those caught in adultery are to have eyes put out. When king's son is found guilty he insists on the punishment. He finally compromises by having one of his own and one of his son's eyes put out.

d: Ruler has son beheaded for rape.
Captain hangs own son for violating order not to enter enemy city.
Gardener made king by minister decides against him in law case and returns lands to plaintiff.
Irrevocable judgment of king upheld.
a: King leaves laws that must be kept until his death. Years later he has his bones sent back to that land to let people know that he is dead and they are free.

d: Short-sighted judgments.
King Lear judgment.
r: Type 510; BP II 47, III 305; *Cox Nos. 208 226; *Hartland FLJ IV 308; *Oesterley No. 273; Herbert III 201; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 183 No. 124.
a: A king flattered by his elder daughters and angered by the seeming indifference, though real love, of the youngest, banishes the youngest and favors the elder daughters.

d: Other judgments and decrees.
Decree that hero must wed only a virgin.
Judgment: pardon given if hero produces the lady about whom he has boasted.
Judgment: thief to be pardoned if he can steal king's treasure without being caught.
Judgments and decrees miscellaneous motifs.
Virgin Mary reverses judgments of church.

d: Deity grants woman two sons, one to be wise and ugly and the other a fool and handsome.

d: Woman requires husband free from jealousy.
Vow to marry first person performing certain act.

Vow to wed no man who cannot perform certain feat.

d: Oath to marry daughters only into family with bridegroom for each daughter.

d: Vow not to eat before learning secret.

d: Vow to find vanished sister.

d: Vow never to refuse food to any man.

d: Vow never to flee in fear of death.

Vow: never to fight with brother.

Vow not to devastate country or take revenge after release.

Vow never to accept a man who does not know any sport.

Vow never to touch money and to give what anyone begs for.

d: Pledge to say but a single phrase.
r: *Types 360, 1697; BP II 561ff.; Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 37 No. 44; India: *Thompson-Balys.
a: In carrying out this agreement the men innocently confess a crime.

d: Promise made merely as a matter of form not binding.

d: Land grants (bargains).
Price set on one's head.

Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3400, Legends No. 757; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 49, 67 Nos. 330, 510, Espinosa Jr.
a: (Faust, Theophilus.)

d: Man unwittingly sells soul to devil.
a: He jestingly offers to sell his soul. Devil in disguise buys it.

d: Man goes to well at midnight on Old Christmas to see water turned into wine.
a: Just as it turns into wine the devil takes him, or injures him.

d: Man sells soul to devil in return for devil's building house (barn, etc.).
Man bequeaths soul to devil.
Jews must repay devil's help by giving tribute of persons each year.
Formulas for selling one's soul to  devil.
Man sells soul to devil for visit home in boat that sails through sky.
Man sells soul to devil for magic power to escape capture.
Man sells soul to devil for devil's doing one specific job.
Person sells soul to devil in return for the granting of wishes.
Devil agrees to help man with robberies.
Devil as helper of robber refuses to let women's ornaments be stolen.
a: They are his own weapons.

d: Devil at gallows repudiates his bargain with robber.
r: *Krappe Archivum Romanicum VII 470ff.; *Wesselski Mdrchen 244 No. 54; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: Ring turns to rope. The judge cannot find a rope and is about to release the thief because of the miracle. But the ring in the box presented by the devil as a bribe turns out to be a rope. The man is hanged.

d: Devil as substitute for day laborer at mowing.
a: He mows with a magic sickle. The evil overseer tries to keep up with him and dies of overexhaustion.

d: Devil to help gambler in exchange for one task yearly.
With his whole heart: devil carries off judge.
r: *Type 1186; **Taylor PMLA XXXVI 35ff., also in Bryan and Dempster Sources and Analogues of Chaucer's Canterbury Tales 26974; *Herbert III 592; *Fb "ridefoged" III 53b; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) Nos. 81, 807; *Robinson Complete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer (Cambridge, Mass., 1933) 809 (Friar's Tale).
a: The devil refuses to take anything not offered him with the whole heart. He hears the judge (advocate) cursed for fraud with such sincerity that he carries him off.

d: Devil bargains to help man become priest.
a: He must not later exorcise him from people.

d: The devil helps man study for priesthood.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3266, Legends Nos. 400ff.
a: For this, he must promise the devil his soul. Having become a great priest, the man finds means to save himself.

d: The devil makes the herdsman's son a priest in return for a whistle.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3269, Legends Nos. 413f.
a: After quarreling with the devil, who asked to repair the whistle during Mass, the priest forgets all he learned and does not know how to hold Mass. Is beaten.

d: Devil bargains to help man win woman.
r: *Loomis White Magic 113; Alphabet No. 64; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 66 No. 508A*, Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda. Cf. Cosquin Itudes 545ff.

d: Servant makes pact with devil denying Christ to secure nobleman's daughter.

d: Pacts with the devil, sealed in blood, made ineffective by a saint.

d: Promise to dying man broken.

d: Dying monster's request and promise.

Thief cursed.
Man who betrays secrets cursed.
Earth cursed.
Curse on a deity.
Curse: god to live life of a cat for twelve full years in house of huntsman on earth.
Irrevocable curse.
r: Penzer VI 103 n. 1, 162 n. 1; Irish myth: Cross; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Curse given to negate good wish.
a: Odin gives man life three times the normal; Thor ordains that in each he is to commit crime. Odin gives him the choicest weapons; Thor denies him landed property, etc.

d: Curse: appetite of twelve men.
a: Given with the gift of twelve men's strength.

d: Curse: eternal life without eternal youth.
Method of cursing.
Curse by "building a fire of stones" in fireplace.
a: The person who removes the stones is cursed.

d: Enduring and overcoming curses.
Release from curse with birth of child.
Curse transferred to another person or thing.
r: Irish: Plummer clxxiii, *Cross, Beal XXI 326, O'Suilleabhain 73.

d: Curse removed when victims reform.
Curse changed by God into blessing.
Curse on everybody on earth who listens to the fatal mentioning of trolls' names, is evaded by person in cave, because he is in the earth.
Curse mitigated by deity when superhuman task is performed.
Miscellaneous ways to overcome curses.
Release from curse by burning vomit.
Release from curse by putting pins around horse's heart and then boiling it.
Release from curse by burning animal in straw pile.
Release from curse by heating the colter of the plow in the stove.
Release from curse by pricking louse and hanging it on wall.
Release from curse by putting a five cent piece in the churn.
Release from curse by putting a piece of silver in the gun.
Curses on persons.
Curse: bodily injury.
Curse: loss of eye.
r: *Type 1331; *BP II 219 n. 1; Irish myth: *Cross; and notes to +J2074.

d: Curse: toads from mouth.
Curse: fire to burn hands and feet.
Curse: arm to fall off.
Curse: hand of person cursed to drop off.
Curse: wound not to heal.
Wicked stepmother cursed to have fire lit under her.
Curse: leprosy.
r: India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 1050.

d: Curse of sterility on wife of enemy.
Curse: head to split in seven pieces.
Curse: to be plagued by nightmares.
Curse: to be carried off by evil spirit.
r: Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 456; Hdwb. d. Mdrchens I 547a nn.

d: Endless sleep given Endymion.
Curse: to be swallowed by a siren.
Curse: not to taste food from own table.
a: Food always seized by harpies.

d: Curse: prince to fall in love with witch's daughter.
Curse: monstrous birth.
Curse: "What I carry may you carry; what you carry may I carry."
a: Cat thus causes ungrateful pregnant woman to bear cats and herself to bear twin girls.

d: Jealous sisters curse the child one of them may have by the god Thor, so that it never will grow nor thrive.
Curse: humiliation.
Curse: man (poet) to kiss a leper.
Curse: hero not to be able to stand the sight of blood.
Girl bewitched so that no man will remain faithful to her.
Curse: hero to remain as dead till the curser dies.
Dying father condemns weak son to be servant of his brothers.
Curse: failure in all undertakings.
Curse: man's sword will fail in danger.
Curse: when brothers' swords bite the very best, they will all be killed by a single man.
Curse: deformity.
Curse: descendants to be unshapely.
Curse: she-wolf to carry off man's genitals.
Curse: privation.
Curse: lack of food, shelter, good company.
Curse of childlessness.
Curse laid on unborn child; it is stillborn.
Giant cursed: may neither heaven nor earth receive him.
Curse: undertaking dangerous quest.
Curse: undertaking dangerous revenge of father.
Curse: to sink into the earth.
r: Tupper and Ogle Walter Map 91; India: Thompson-Balys; Eskimo (Central Eskimo): Boas RBAE VI 585.

d: Curse: ground shall swallow children.
Curse: death.
r: England, U.S.: *Baughman; Jewish: Neuman; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 126.

d: Death by suicide.
Death by drowning.
Curse: insanity.
Curse: corpse to be put in three different places after person's death.
Curse: change of sex.
Curse: restlessness.
r: (Cf. +K1837.4.) Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Lagerholm lxi ii.

d: Hero cursed to restlessness (except on boat or in tent), till he sees girl.
Curse: not to be able to love the same woman more than twelve months.
Thrall cursed to sit on chest and yell and never have rest.
Curse: couple to wander until new seat of race is pointed out.
Curse of petrifaction.
Miscellaneous curses on persons.
Curse: woman will not travel far.
Curses on families.
r: Irish: Plummer clxxiv, *Cross; England, Wales, U.S.: Baughman; Icelandic: *Boberg; Greek: Fox 120 (Tantalus), Grote I 244f.

d: Curse: children will be sick.
Curse: descendants of nine robbers never to exceed nine.
Curse on village: descendants never to exceed certain number.
Curse: race to lose sovereignty.
Curse on tribe (district).
r: Irish myth: *Cross; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Curse of a woman against her caste: they should remain unclothed and untaught.
Curses on objects or animals.
Curses on animals.
Curse: cow will give red milk.
Curse: milk will not turn to butter.
Cursing to make pigs lean.
r: Irish myth: Cross; French Canadian: Sister Marie Ursule.

d: Curse: horses will die.
Curse: horse will be lame.
Curse on land.
Curse on a city.
Curse on a city: never to grow.
Curse on river.
Curse on river or sea: no fish in it from that day.
Curse on lake.
Curse on lake: fire from lake will burn the forest around it.
Curses miscellaneous.
Presence of cursed person brings disaster to land.
Whomsoever demons curse is blessed, and vice versa.
